intro: Pulsatilla patens var. albolutea, commonly known as the white pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that range from white to pale yellow. The plant typically grows in alpine meadows and rocky soils, preferring well-drained conditions. Its leaves are palmately divided, and the plant is known for its early spring bloom, often emerging as one of the first flowers to appear after snow melt. It is a perennial species with a short stem and is often cultivated for its ornamental value.
